Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: THE REDUCTION OF TWO STROKE ENGINE EMISSIONS BY MEANS OF ROTARY EXHAUST VALVES
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to reduce two stroke emissions while improving overall engine efficiencies. Engine emissions directly impact the environment, wildlife, and public health. Small engines used in powersports and small lightweight ground transportation are becoming a significant source of emissions. The technology developed in this effort will yield a low cost high power density engine with reduced emissions output. Transportation manufactures have limited low cost options to improve emissions and this technology will provide a commercial incentive to implement; keeping cost low while achieving lower emissions outputs.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop two stroke engine technology that reduces engine emissions. Two stoke engines are low cost with high power density but despite these advantages, the two stroke engines' major disadvantage is the emissions produced by the engine. The disadvantages are inherent to the design of the traditional two stroke engine with the lubrication oil being mixed with the fuel and the port design allowing unburnt hydrocarbons to exit the engine. This project will address these shortcomings of the traditional two stoke developing an engine with an emissions profile similar to that of a four stoke engine.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Strange Development's NSF Phase I SBIR continued funding the research and development of their REVolution clean two stroke technology. The heart of Strange Development's REvolution technology is the Rotary Exhaust Valve. The Rotary Exhaust Valve controls cylinder trapped mass, unlike conventional two stroke technology, reducing emissions, improving power density, and is a key enabler to improve the durability of the engine. The Rotary Exhaust Valve can control the "cross talk" between the intake and exhaust ports and in doing so can control air flowing from and through the cylinder. As a result, hydrocarbon emissions that are typically associated with two stroke engines can be drastically reduced.

Strange Development's Phase I effort focused on designing, manufacturing, and testing a technology demonstration engine to showcase the benefits of Strange Development's REVolution technology. Strange Development's goal was to design, develop, and produce a running prototype engine equipped with their Rotary Exhaust Valve technology. Strange Development set out to develop hardware while iterating the design based on simulation, manufacturability, produce a running prototype, conduct testing to evaluate emissions, and conduct testing on the functionality of rotary valve system itself. 

This engine development effort was done at Strange Development's headquarters and R&D center located in Fenton Michigan. Ultimately the goal was to attain data demonstrating a reduction in emissions with REVolution technology however, an extensive design, development, and manufacturing process had to be accomplished prior to the testing stage of the Phase I effort. The critical steps of Strange Development's Phase I effort are bulleted below.

  • Removing Oil form the Combustion Process Eliminating Oils Contribution to HC, CO, and PM Emissions Content
  • Durability Evaluation of Base Engine Components and Rotary Exhaust System
  • Reduce HC and O2 Content in Exhaust Gas with Rotary Exhaust Valve

Strange Development's Phase I effort successfully reduced HC, CO, and CO2 emissions along with reducing O2 content clearly demonstrating that the REVolution technology can reduce two-stroke emissions. Not only was the demonstration of the technology successful but the data attained during testing can now be used to correlate scavenging to fully optimize valve geometry and phasing for a further reduction in HC and O2 content. Key technology demonstration takeaways bulleted below.

  • Over 300% Reduction in HC compared to traditional two-stroke engine
  • HC to be further reduced to meet four stroke target - planed DI and valve optimization in next development phase
  • Over 200% reduction in CO compared to competitive four stroke
  • Over 400% reduction in CO2 compared to competitive four stroke

Strange Development engineered and tested the effectiveness of utilizing a rotary exhaust valve to reduce two stroke engine emissions. The achievements, during Phase I, in attaining data demonstrating the effectiveness of this technology, to reduce emissions, will significantly impact the development work on two stroke engines. These engines were no longer looked at as a viable option for propulsion solutions and cleaner alternatives have been replacing this type of engine. The results from Strange Development's effort will impact future propulsion system decisions requiring high power density clean technology.
